claim:
Consider the following background information: A 38-year-old woman undergoes a partial thyroidectomy for an enlarged thyroid gland compressing the trachea. During surgery, a young surgeon ligates the inferior thyroid arteries as close to the poles as possible to prevent intraoperative hemorrhage. 2 weeks later, the patient presents to the outpatient clinic with hoarseness.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: Phrenic nerve damage is the most likely cause of the patient"s hoarseness.

supporting.text: The phrenic nerve is not anatomically close to the thyroid gland and is not typically at risk during thyroidectomy, making its damage an unlikely cause of hoarseness.

attacks.text: The phrenic nerve is not anatomically close to the thyroid gland and is not typically at risk during thyroidectomy, making its damage an unlikely cause of hoarseness.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the phrenic nerve, is the nerve most commonly injured during thyroidectomy and is the likely cause of hoarseness.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve runs in close proximity to the inferior thyroid artery, which was ligated during surgery, increasing the risk of iatrogenic injury.
Hoarseness can also result from non-nerve-related causes such as post-intubation vocal cord trauma or laryngeal edema.

supporting.text: Hoarseness after thyroidectomy is most commonly caused by damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which runs near the thyroid gland and is at risk during surgery.

attacks.text: Hoarseness after thyroidectomy is most commonly caused by damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which runs near the thyroid gland and is at risk during surgery.
The phrenic nerve is not anatomically close to the thyroid gland and is unlikely to be damaged during thyroidectomy.
In rare cases, the phrenic nerve may be anatomically variant and pass near the thyroid gland, making it susceptible to injury.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in thyroid surgery due to its close anatomical relationship with the thyroid gland.

supporting.text: The inferior thyroid arteries are ligated during the procedure, but the phrenic nerve is located more laterally and is not directly associated with these vessels.

attacks.text: The inferior thyroid arteries are ligated during the procedure, but the phrenic nerve is located more laterally and is not directly associated with these vessels.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the phrenic nerve, is anatomically closer to the inferior thyroid arteries and is at higher risk of injury during thyroid surgery.
The phrenic nerve primarily innervates the diaphragm, and its injury would not typically cause hoarseness, further supporting that it is not the likely cause.
Intraoperative nerve monitoring studies show that the recurrent laryngeal nerve is injured in approximately 3-5% of thyroidectomies, making it a more probable cause.

supporting.text: The phrenic nerve primarily innervates the diaphragm, and its damage would more likely cause respiratory symptoms rather than hoarseness.

attacks.text: The phrenic nerve primarily innervates the diaphragm, and its damage would more likely cause respiratory symptoms rather than hoarseness.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the phrenic nerve, is the most likely cause of hoarseness after thyroid surgery due to its anatomical proximity.
In rare cases, phrenic nerve damage can occur simultaneously with recurrent laryngeal nerve damage, complicating the diagnosis.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve is routinely identified and preserved during thyroidectomy, making its injury less likely unless surgical technique was flawed.
Intraoperative nerve monitoring is increasingly used to prevent recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, further reducing its likelihood as a cause of hoarseness.
